page.title: 01LAND S.W. OF SHERBURN
page.content: An area of Farmland, intensively cultivated. The northern third originally Lake Pickering a post glacial lake. The land rises up fairly abruptly to escarpment or Yorkshire Wolds. Crops are sugar beet, potatoes, wheat, barley oil seed rape. Kale and turnips for sheep grazing. Small village of East Heslerton stands on A64 Leeds to Scarborough. Which also cuts across Sherburn Village. About 10 farms on area. The soil on upland plateau can be very thin and lots of chalk and flints. The Wolds are noted for good malting barley. 6 small shelter belt woods mainly broad leaved around farm steadings. One other minor road from north to south. General aspect of rolling wolds of large cultivated fields broken by clumps of farm steads surrounded by shelter belts.
